verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh. For by a strong hand he will let them go, and by a strong hand he will drive them out of his land.”
verses.comment: Direct statement from God; 'strong hand' indicates forceful power.

verses.text: God spoke to Moses and said to him, “I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Name 'LORD' (YHWH) affirmed; significant for covenant.

verses.text: I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob as God Almighty, but by my name the LORD I was not known to them.
verses.comment: God reveals new aspect of His name; 'God Almighty' is 'El Shaddai'.

verses.text: I also established my covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, the land where they lived as foreigners.
verses.comment: Refers to Abrahamic covenant and patriarchs living as 'foreigners' or 'sojourners'.

verses.text: Moreover, I have heard the groaning of the Israelites, whom the Egyptians are keeping as slaves, and I have remembered my covenant.
verses.comment: God responds because of His covenant promises.

verses.text: Therefore, say to the Israelites, ‘I am the LORD, and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians. I will rescue you from their slavery, and I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with great judgments.
verses.comment: ‘Outstretched arm’ is a figurative expression for mighty power.

verses.text: I will take you as my people, and I will be your God. Then you shall know that I am the LORD your God, who brings you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.
verses.comment: God reaffirms the covenant ‘I will be your God.’

verses.text: And I will bring you into the land that I swore to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob; I will give it to you as a possession. I am the LORD.”
verses.comment: References God’s oath to the patriarchs.

verses.text: Moses spoke thus to the Israelites, but they did not listen to Moses because of their broken spirit and cruel slavery.
verses.comment: ‘Broken spirit’ literally ‘shortness of spirit’; oppression silenced hope.

verses.text: So the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: God initiates further command.

verses.text: “Go in, speak to Pharaoh king of Egypt, that he let the Israelites go out of his land.”
verses.comment: Direct instruction to Moses for Pharaoh.

verses.text: But Moses said to the LORD, “Look, the Israelites have not listened to me; how then shall Pharaoh listen to me, since I am of uncircumcised lips?”
verses.comment: ‘Uncircumcised lips’ means ‘not eloquent’ or ‘unskilled in speech.’

verses.text: Then the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, and gave them a command for the Israelites and for Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring the Israelites out of the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Instruction includes both Moses and Aaron here.

verses.text: These are the heads of their fathers’ families: The sons of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi; these are the clans of Reuben.
verses.comment: Genealogical listing begins; names as in earlier sources.

verses.text: The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman; these are the clans of Simeon.
verses.comment: Genealogical sequence; notable mention of Shaul's mother.

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Levi, according to their genealogies: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari; and Levi lived 137 years.
verses.comment: Levi’s lifespan is specified here.

verses.text: The sons of Gershon: Libni and Shimei, according to their families.
verses.comment: Gershon's line detailed.

verses.text: The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 years.
verses.comment: Kohath’s sons and age listed.

verses.text: The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. These are the clans of Levi according to their genealogies.
verses.comment: Merari’s descendants; summary of Levi’s family.

verses.text: Amram took Jochebed his father’s sister as his wife, and she bore him Aaron and Moses. Amram lived 137 years.
verses.comment: Marriage between close relatives noted; consistent with other sources.

verses.text: The sons of Izhar: Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.
verses.comment: Izhar’s sons; Korah is well-known from later stories.

verses.text: The sons of Uzziel: Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
verses.comment: Uzziel’s descendants; Elzaphan appears in Leviticus.

verses.text: Aaron took Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon, as his wife, and she bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
verses.comment: Aaron’s wife’s lineage and children given.

verses.text: The sons of Korah: Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph; these are the clans of the Korahites.
verses.comment: Korahite descendants are significant in later biblical history.

verses.text: Eleazar, Aaron’s son, took one of the daughters of Putiel as his wife, and she bore him Phinehas. These are the heads of the fathers’ houses of the Levites by their clans.
verses.comment: Phinehas plays an important role later; families are consolidated.

verses.text: These are the Aaron and Moses to whom the LORD said, “Bring the Israelites out of the land of Egypt by their companies.”
verses.comment: Clarifies which Moses and Aaron are being discussed.

verses.text: They are the ones who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt to bring out the Israelites from Egypt, these are the Moses and Aaron.
verses.comment: Repetition for emphasis and identification.

verses.text: And it came to pass on the day when the LORD spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt,
verses.comment: Introductory note to next exchange.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying, “I am the LORD. Speak to Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I say to you.”
verses.comment: God again insists on His message being delivered to Pharaoh.

verses.text: But Moses said to the LORD, “Look, I am of uncircumcised lips; how will Pharaoh listen to me?”
verses.comment: Repeats Moses’ hesitation. ‘Uncircumcised lips’ = lacking eloquence.
